threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

attributes.magic: ELF 32-bit MSB executable, SPARC, version 1 (SYSV), statically linked, stripped

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects suspicious single byte XORed keyword 'Mozilla/5.0' - it uses yara's XOR modifier and therefore cannot print the XOR key. You can use the CyberChef recipe linked in the reference field to brute force the used key.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects suspicious single byte XORed keyword 'Mozilla/5.0' - it uses yara's XOR modifier and therefore cannot print the XOR key. You can use the CyberChef recipe linked in the reference field to brute force the used key.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: This MIPS32 ELF binary is identified as a DDoS botnet agent, likely a variant of Gafgyt or Mirai. Key indicators include the presence of the string 'POST /cdn-cgi/', a specific IOC used in application-layer DDoS attacks to target or bypass Cloudflare-protected infrastructures. Decompilation reveals repetitive function structures (sub_db2c, sub_de8c, etc.) that manually manipulate ELF headers and coprocessor registers, typical of packed or obfuscated IoT malware. The binary also contains logic for standard HTTP request construction and output suppression via '/dev/null', further confirming its malicious network-attack capabilities.
